user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TranslatePath:
```c
int32 OS_TranslatePath(const char *VirtualPath, char *LocalPath)
{
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    int32                         return_code;
    const char *                  name_ptr;
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    size_t                        SysMountPointLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathBegin;

    /*
    ** Check to see if the path pointers are NULL
    */
    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(VirtualPath);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(LocalPath);

    /*
    ** Check length
    */
    VirtPathLen = OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN);
    if (VirtPathLen >= OS_MAX_PATH_LEN)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
    }

    /* checks to see if there is a '/' somewhere in the path */
    name_ptr = strrchr(VirtualPath, '/');
    if (name_ptr == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* strrchr returns a pointer to the last '/' char, so we advance one char */
    name_ptr = name_ptr + 1;
    if (memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
    }

    SysMountPointLen = 0;
    VirtPathBegin    = VirtPathLen;

    /*
    ** All valid Virtual paths must start with a '/' character
    */
    if (VirtualPath[0] != '/')
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* Get a reference lock, as a filesystem check could take some time. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)VirtualPath, &token);

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }
    else
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0)
        {
            SysMountPointLen = OS_strnlen(filesys->system_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt));
            VirtPathBegin    = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));
            if (SysMountPointLen < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(LocalPath, filesys->system_mountpt, SysMountPointLen);
            }
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (VirtPathLen < VirtPathBegin)
        {
            return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
        }
        else
        {
            VirtPathLen -= VirtPathBegin;
            if ((SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen) < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(&LocalPath[SysMountPointLen], &VirtualPath[VirtPathBegin], VirtPathLen);
                LocalPath[SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen] = 0;
            }
            else
            {
                return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TranslatePath:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_MAX_PATH_LEN 64
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
...
#define OS_MAX_FILE_NAME 20
...
#define OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG (-103)
...
#define OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID (-108)
...
#define OS_FS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (-104)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_filesys_internal_record_t OS_filesys_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char device_name[OS_FS_DEV_NAME_LEN]; /**< The name of the underlying block device, if applicable */
    char volume_name[OS_FS_VOL_NAME_LEN];
    char system_mountpt[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN]; /**< The name/prefix where the contents are accessible in the host
                                                   operating system */
    char virtual_mountpt[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN]; /**< The name/prefix in the OSAL Virtual File system exposed to applications
                                            */
    char *            address;
    size_t            blocksize;
    osal_blockcount_t numblocks;
    uint8             flags;
    uint8             fstype;
} OS_filesys_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM 0x10
...
#define OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (OS_MAX_PATH_LEN+OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in the supplied OS_TranslatePath function are invariant at compile time. There are no loop constructs (while/for/do-while) in this function whose controlling expression would be constant; the code only contains if statements whose conditions depend on runtime values or function results. Specific points considered:

- if (VirtPathLen >= OS_MAX_PATH_LEN): VirtPathLen is computed at runtime via OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN), so the comparison depends on the input string content.
- if (name_ptr == NULL) and subsequent name_ptr usage: name_ptr is the result of strrchr(VirtualPath, '/'), i.e., runtime dependent.
- if (memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) == NULL): memchr result depends on the runtime contents of the string.
- if (VirtualPath[0] != '/') : checks the first character of the runtime input string.
- return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(...); followed by if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS) and later if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS): return_code is set by the called function at runtime.
- if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0): depends on the runtime state of the filesys record.
- if (SysMountPointLen < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN): SysMountPointLen is computed at runtime from filesys->system_mountpt.
- if (VirtPathLen < VirtPathBegin): both variables are computed/updated at runtime (VirtPathBegin initially set to VirtPathLen but may be changed when a matching mount point is found), so the comparison is not invariant.
- if ((SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen) < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN): both lengths are runtime values.

Note: Macros invoked (OS_CHECK_POINTER, BUGCHECK) and helper functions (OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_strnlen, memchr, strrchr) could contain control-flow constructs internally, but those bodies are not provided here. Based on the provided code alone, there are no invariant controlling expressions that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 (subject to inspection of the macros/functions if their internals are in-scope for rule checking).
